item.title: Kerry Joins Angelina Jolie in Deploring Sexual Violence in War
item.description: The secretary of state spoke at a conference in London featuring the actress that sought ways to bring perpetrators to justice.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: Critique of Narendra Modi in College Magazine Leads to Arrest of Seven
item.description: Six students and a college principal were arrested at a Kerala college after a student-run magazine published a negative article on Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 13
item.description: People at the Gateway of India in Mumbai, Maharashtra, during a high tide.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: People making a run during a high tide near the Gateway of India in Mumbai, Maharashtra. The Indian Meteorological Department has declared the onset of the monsoon season, which accounts for 80 percent of India's annual rainfall.

item.title: Obama Says He Will Decide on Military Support for Iraq in ‘Days Ahead’
item.description: With Iraq in crisis, President Obama made a statement about the situation on Friday before leaving on a trip to North Dakota and California.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Barack Obama spoke outside the White House.

item.title: 3 Israeli Teenagers Said to Be Kidnapped in West Bank
item.description: Initial reports said the teens were last heard from on Thursday night on their way to a hitchhiking area south of Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Bergdahl, Back in U.S., Is Treated at Army Medical Center
item.description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the former prisoner of war, will begin a “reintegration process” at an Army medical facility in Texas.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Issues Call to Arms Against Sunni Militants
item.description: The most senior Shiite cleric in the country, Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, called on Iraqis to assist the government’s fight against the Sunni militants who have seized broad stretches of Iraq.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN, SUADAD AL-SALHY and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Iraqi police officers dug trenches at a checkpoint in the town of Taji, outside Baghdad, on Friday, as security forces bolstered defenses in the capital.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Long on the Edges of Afghan Power, Abdullah Moves Toward Its Center
item.description: The front-runner in Afghanistan’s presidential election, Abdullah Abdullah, has pushed ahead by excelling at the central skill of Afghan political leadership: making deals.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah garnered 45 percent of the vote in the first round of elections in Afghanistan, compared with 33 percent for his closest competitor, Ashraf Ghani.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Businessman Guilty of Killing and Eating Tigers
item.description: The trial took place two months after the Chinese government issued a new interpretation of an existing ban on trade in endangered species that said that eating a tiger or other protected animal would be punishable by prison.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Xiongsen Bear and Tiger Park in Guilin, which holds more than 1,300 tigers. Exemptions to China's wildlife protection law permit captive breeding of endangered species for exhibition.

item.title: Ukraine Claims Full Control of Port City
item.description: Government forces said that they had routed separatists in Mariupol and had destroyed two tanks that Kiev said had come from Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: U.N. Warns of Rights Abuses and Hundreds Dead in Iraq Fighting
item.description: The top human rights official at the United Nations expressed “extreme alarm” over extrajudicial killings, rape and the shelling of civilians.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Fears About Iraq Continue to Push Up Oil Prices
item.description: For a second day, prices are rising modestly as traders worry over instability in the Middle East.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: A photograph taken in March showing a member of the Iraqi Navy standing guard as a tanker loads crude oil at Iraq's southern port of Basra.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Cleaning Up the Vatican
item.description: The pope is adamant that one of the church's most secretive institutions will become open and accountable.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VALLELY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Rape and the Warrior's Code
item.description: In the words of Australia's top general, "every soldier has a simple, terrible choice: to be a protector or a perpetrator."
item.dc:creator: By JULIA BAIRD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China and Japan Face Off Over Documentation of Wartime Atrocities
item.description: Japan has filed a formal complaint after China submitted an application to Unesco’s Memory of the World Register on atrocities committed by the Japanese during World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Visitors viewing the names of victims at the Nanjing Massacre Memorial Hall in Nanjing, China. Beijing has submitted an application to Unesco's Memory of the World Register that includes records on the massacre.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Debate Rages After Death Sentences Overturned in Child Prostitution Case
item.description: Reaction to a court ruling against death sentences for two men for crimes committed against an 11-year-old girl has highlighted broader issues including corruption, prejudice and justice.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Tang Hui speaking to reporters near the Hunan Provincial People's High Court in Changsha last year.

item.title: Lens Blog: A German Rebel in South Africa
item.description: Jürgen Schadeberg left the ruins of Nazi Germany to pursue photography in South Africa, where he documented the black struggle and trained a generation of photographers.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: One of the first surfboards, which was made by an Indian enthusiast. Durban, South Africa. 1951.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The People’s Liberation Army, in Lights
item.description: The Hong Kong light and laser show this week appeared to include gigantic Chinese characters that read “People’s Liberation Army” on the side of the garrison’s waterfront headquarters, alarming many locals.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: World Briefing: Moldova: European Union Plans to Invest Millions
item.description: The European Union said it would finance projects worth about $68 million in Moldova, a former Soviet republic that is prepared to sign an association agreement with the European bloc amid protests from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Jamaica: Government Aims to Relax Marijuana Laws
item.description: Jamaica’s government on Thursday announced a major rethinking of its marijuana laws, including plans to partly decriminalize small amounts of marijuana and to allow possession for religious, scientific and medical purposes.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Compensation for Nazi Seizures Increased
item.description: A Berlin court has ordered Germany to pay the heirs of Jewish owners of a department store chain about $68 million in additional compensation for property seized by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: Troops Exchange Fire With Rwandan Soldiers
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda sent more troops to their shared border on Thursday after gunfire briefly broke out for a second day.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Greece Wars With Courts Over Ways to Slash Budget
item.description: Greek judges continue to contest the government’s attempts to cut salaries, pensions and jobs of public workers to reduce the country’s debt.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Members of the Finance Ministry’s cleaning staff clashed with the police in Athens on Thursday. Nearly 400 laid-off workers want their jobs back.

item.title: Building Nuclear Weapon Would Take Years, Not Months, Iran Says in Report
item.description: The estimate contradicts both classified assessments by the United States government and many outside experts.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry has told senators it would take Iran “about two months” to amass fuel for a nuclear weapon.

item.title: Video: The Goal Heard Round Brazil
item.description: When Neymar drove the ball into the back of the net for Brazil’s first goal, pandemonium ensued around the host country.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
